moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8
comment: This is the first deviation from Psakhis-Shirov, of round 7 (two rounds earlier) , where Shirov played 8...Na5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1
comment: Clearly Black wouldn't like to face b2-b4-b5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5
comment: It would appear this is something especially prepared for Shirov. By preventing ...c7-c5 he undermines Black's plan and still can play b2-b4.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4
comment: The knight would seem to be a little too far afield.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6
comment: But, perhaps the same can be said of White's queen! If she had just retreated the game would be interesting, but now it's a walk on a razor's edge.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4
comment: guarding square a8 to prevent ...Rb8-a8 which would trap Qa6

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6
1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7
comment: Black has sacrificed two pawns, but will soon regain one by capturing Pc5. So, is the stuck Qa6 good compensation for a one-pawn sacrifice?

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5
comment: How about for a two-pawn sacrifice? It's not at all clear Black can forcibly regain the material or win Qa6. At least there's the immediate threat to Nb5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4
comment: threatening Re1 and probably preparing ...Nd7-c5-b3xc1 to undermine all of White's queen-side pawns. How Black might do all this and somehow switch the play toward Kg1 is as yet unclear.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5
comment: All of White's pieces are targets and they can't coordinate to do anything together!

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3
comment: providing a support point where Qc6 can escape (a4 or c4)

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3 Nc3
comment: Shirov is keeping White's queen tied to Nc7 and blocking the c-file to prevent the queen from retreating or being supported by a rook. That he threatens Rb1 is also good.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3 Nc3 26. Qxc4 Qxc4 27. bxc4 Rxb1 28. Rxb1 Nxb1
comment: But, it cost White an exchange to clear the board and he's surely lost in the ending.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3 Nc3 26. Qxc4 Qxc4 27. bxc4 Rxb1 28. Rxb1 Nxb1 29. Bb6 Nc3 30. Kf1 Na4 31. Ba5 f5 32. Ne3 e4 33. Ned5 Kf7 34. f3 exf3 35. exf3 Bd4 36. Nb5

1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3 Nc3 26. Qxc4 Qxc4 27. bxc4 Rxb1 28. Rxb1 Nxb1 29. Bb6 Nc3 30. Kf1 Na4 31. Ba5 f5 32. Ne3 e4 33. Ned5 Kf7 34. f3 exf3 35. exf3 Bd4 36. Nb5 Bc5
comment: Black threatens ...Na4-b2xc4 and it is probably going to be very difficult or impossible for White to defend the pawn when his bishop can't help directly.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. g3 Bg7 4. Bg2 d6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. Nc3 Nc6 7. O-O a6 8. Re1 Rb8 9. Rb1 Na5 10. Qa4 b6 11. c5 Bd7 12. Qa3 Nc4 13. Qxa6 b5 14. Nh4 dxc5 15. dxc5 c6 16. Bxc6 Qc7 17. Bxd7 Nxd7 18. Nxb5 Qxc5 19. a4 Qb4 20. Ng2 Nc5 21. Qc6 Nxa4 22. Nc7 Rfc8 23. Bf4 e5 24. Be3 Rb7 25. b3 Nc3 26. Qxc4 Qxc4 27. bxc4 Rxb1 28. Rxb1 Nxb1 29. Bb6 Nc3 30. Kf1 Na4 31. Ba5 f5 32. Ne3 e4 33. Ned5 Kf7 34. f3 exf3 35. exf3 Bd4 36. Nb5 Bc5 37. Ke2
comment: It's a little unusual for someone to make a move and then resign (not unheard of, just unusual) , so I don't know whether White resigned here or perhaps lost by time forfeit. But, Pc4 is weak, so he may have forseen a concrete variation where it's lost. Without that pawn White can't hold back Black.
